study_goal: The researchers were investigating the role of gut microbiota in the development of cardiovascular disease (CVD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings related to Maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maltodextrin as a placebo compared to whey protein supplementation on systemic microvascular function in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in endothelial-dependent or endothelial-independent microvascular vasodilation with maltodextrin supplementation, unlike whey protein. Maltodextrin served as an inert placebo with no observable therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (NYHA classes I/II), aged 64.5±6.2 years in the whey protein group and 68.2±8.8 years in the placebo group.

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of whey protein, soy protein, and maltodextrin (placebo) on performance, muscle damage, and redox responses following speed-endurance training in soccer players.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (placebo) showed similar performance deterioration and muscle damage markers as whey and soy protein, except for a temporary impairment in 10m speed at 24h. No significant differences in redox status were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Ten well-trained, male soccer players.
study_duration: 3-day experimental period with two speed-endurance training sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral probiotics containing maltodextrin as a bulking agent could alter the clinical course of chalaziosis in children.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic supplementation significantly reduced the time required for complete resolution of chalazion compared to medical treatment alone, with no significant complications reported. Maltodextrin was used as a bulking agent but its specific effects were not isolated or discussed.
population_specificity: 26 children suffering from chalaziosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified for maltodextrin; probiotics contained ≥ 1×10^9 live cells of each strain per dose.
study_duration: Evaluated at 2-week intervals for 3 months, with potential extension for another 3-month cycle if needed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of saffron supplementation versus maltodextrin (placebo) on disease severity and oxidative/antioxidant factors in patients with ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in serum levels of malondialdehyde between the saffron and maltodextrin (placebo) groups, indicating maltodextrin had no measurable impact on oxidative stress markers. Saffron showed improvements in antioxidant factors, while maltodextrin did not demonstrate efficacy beyond placebo effects.
population_specificity: 80 mild to moderate ulcerative colitis patients (75 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) against polydextrose (PDX) on cognitive performance, stress response, and gut microbiota in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and did not show significant improvements in cognitive performance or stress response compared to PDX. The placebo group exhibited increased adhesion receptor CD62L on classical monocytes, which was attenuated by PDX.
population_specificity: 18 healthy female participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how maltodextrin supplementation influences the composition of the colonic microbiota and metabolites in healthy adults over 60.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding maltodextrin's effects, focusing instead on wheat bran AXOS supplementation, which was bifidogenic and influenced gut microbiota composition based on initial profiles.
population_specificity: Healthy adults over the age of 60 (n=21, mean BMI 25.2 ± 0.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (placebo) against fermented soy supplementation on heartburn relief, gastrointestinal symptoms, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between maltodextrin and fermented soy for heartburn severity, frequency, or gastrointestinal symptoms. However, maltodextrin did not show improvements in quality-of-life indicators where fermented soy did.
population_specificity: Adults experiencing mild or moderate heartburn.
effective_dosage: Up to 3, 1 g sachets per heartburn incident as needed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of creatine supplementation versus maltodextrin (placebo) combined with resistance training on markers of inflammation and insulin resistance in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no differences between the creatine and maltodextrin groups in any of the analyzed variables, including inflammatory markers and insulin resistance. Both groups showed a reduction in monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), suggesting resistance training alone had an effect.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of a supplement blend containing maltodextrin on performance fatigability and affective responses during exercise.
results_summary: The study found no significant interaction for performance variables, indicating maltodextrin did not notably affect peak torque, average torque, or total work during exercise. Affective responses were assessed but results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 30 men aged 22.3 ± 4.1 years.
effective_dosage: 175 mg of maltodextrin combined with 175 mg of the herbal supplement.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the potential of oat β-glucan and wheat arabinoxylan (not Maltodextrin) to strengthen intestinal barrier function and counteract indomethacin-induced hyperpermeability in the elderly.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Maltodextrin or its effects; it focuses on oat β-glucan and wheat arabinoxylan.
population_specificity: Elderly subjects (≥65 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-exercise maltodextrin ingestion improves resistance exercise performance and affects serum insulin, epinephrine, glucose, and muscle glycogen concentrations.
results_summary: Maltodextrin supplementation did not improve resistance exercise performance despite increasing metabolic substrate availability. It led to decreased epinephrine, decreased serum glucose, and increased insulin concentrations during exercise, but did not enhance glycogen recovery after 1 hour.
population_specificity: Participants completing resistance exercise (angled leg press) under controlled conditions.
study_duration: Acute (single session with measurements taken over 3 hours post-ingestion and 1 hour post-exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of maltodextrin as a placebo compared to a PEA-maltodextrin combination on recovery from muscle-damaging exercise.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding maltodextrin's effects, as it primarily focuses on the comparison between PEA-maltodextrin and maltodextrin placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy young male participants.
study_duration: Intervention was administered over four subsequent days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of synbiotic supplementation versus maltodextrin (placebo) on serum levels of uremic toxins and biochemical parameters in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (placebo) showed no significant effects on uremic factors, biochemical parameters, or inflammation markers compared to the synbiotic group. Phenol levels decreased in both groups, but no significant between-group differences were observed.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients (n=42, placebo group n=21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether carbohydrate (CHO) supplementation, specifically Maltodextrin, affects the Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) during exercise in hypoxia.
results_summary: The study found that CHO supplementation did not alter RPE during 60 minutes of exercise at 50% VO₂max in hypoxia simulating 4200 m. No significant changes in perceived exertion were observed.
population_specificity: Eight male physically active volunteers.

study_goal: The study does not investigate Maltodextrin; it focuses on high-velocity resistance training and creatine supplementation in aging males.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Maltodextrin or its effects.
population_specificity: Untrained healthy aging males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether probiotic supplementation enhances maltodextrin absorption and oxidation during endurance cycling, potentially sparing muscle glycogen for subsequent performance.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation led to a small increase in peak oxidation rates of ingested maltodextrin (0.84 vs. 0.77 g/min), suggesting a modest improvement in carbohydrate utilization during exercise. No significant adverse effects or major performance differences were reported.
population_specificity: Seven male endurance cyclists.
effective_dosage: Initial 8 mL/kg bolus of 10% maltodextrin solution, followed by 2 mL/kg every 15 minutes during exercise.
study_duration: 4 weeks of probiotic or placebo supplementation, separated by a 14-day washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of AXOS and placebo (maltodextrin) on gastrointestinal function and metabolic health in adults with slow GI transit.
results_summary: The study found no change in whole-gut transit time with maltodextrin, but it served as an inert placebo without reported adverse effects. Secondary outcomes were not significantly altered by maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Normoglycemic adults with slow GI transit (>35 h whole-gut transit time) but without constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of probiotic supplementation versus maltodextrin (placebo) on depressive symptoms, quality of life, and biomarkers of oxidative stress and inflammation in post-MI patients.
results_summary: Maltodextrin, used as a placebo, showed no significant improvements in depressive symptoms, quality of life, or biomarkers compared to the probiotic group, indicating it had no measurable therapeutic effect in this context.
population_specificity: 44 patients with a recent myocardial infarction who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention.

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of FOS at varying doses to Maltodextrin (placebo) on gut microbiota composition and diversity.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (10 g/day) did not promote the selective proliferation of Lactobacillus OTUs as observed with FOS. The study found no significant beneficial effects of Maltodextrin on gut microbiota diversity or butyrate-producing bacteria compared to FOS.
population_specificity: 80 participants (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated (phases included basal, dosage, and follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers used maltodextrin as a placebo to compare against the effects of HT and PC supplementation on early atherosclerosis markers.
results_summary: The study did not report any specific effects of maltodextrin, as it was used solely as a placebo control. No adverse effects or benefits related to maltodextrin were mentioned.
population_specificity: Middle-aged, seemingly healthy adults.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the effects of oral taurine supplementation on cycling performance and thermoregulation in the heat, not Maltodextrin.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Maltodextrin or its effects.
population_specificity: 11 healthy males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether maltodextrin, used as a placebo, had any adverse effects on lung function in youth elite athletes compared to creatine supplementation.
results_summary: The study found no significant adverse effects of maltodextrin on airway inflammation or responsiveness, with the placebo group showing stable or slightly improved lung function metrics compared to the creatine group.
population_specificity: Elite soccer players aged 16-21 years.
effective_dosage: Same dosages as creatine monohydrate: 0.3 g·kg⋅d for 1 week (loading phase) and 5 g·d for 7 weeks (maintenance phase).
study_duration: 8 weeks total (1 week loading, 7 weeks maintenance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different creatine supplementation dosages, with maltodextrin used as a placebo or filler, on aging muscle performance and functionality.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in muscle strength, endurance, or physical performance between groups receiving maltodextrin as a placebo or filler, suggesting it had no measurable effect on aging muscle performance.
population_specificity: Aging individuals (specific age range not provided)
effective_dosage: 0.1 g/kg/day, 0.3 g/kg/day, and 0.4 g/kg/day of maltodextrin

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin and whey protein on post-exercise rehydration and gastric emptying rates.
results_summary: The study compared maltodextrin and whey protein during rehydration but did not report specific outcomes for maltodextrin's effectiveness. Gastric emptying rates were measured, but results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Eight healthy male and female participants.
effective_dosage: 35 g of maltodextrin ingested once at the onset of rehydration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of juçara supplementation versus maltodextrin (placebo) on serum fatty acids profile and epigenetic markers in monocytes of obese individuals.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed no significant improvements in serum fatty acids profile or epigenetic markers compared to juçara supplementation. The study did not highlight any specific effects of maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Obese adults (BMI 30.0–39.9 kg/m²), aged 31–59 years, of both genders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (placebo) versus creatine supplementation on exercise-induced apoptotic markers in middle-aged men.
results_summary: Maltodextrin supplementation did not significantly alter apoptotic markers (caspase-3, caspase-9, p53, Bax, IGF-1) before or after exercise, but these markers increased significantly post-exercise in the placebo group. Lactate levels increased similarly in both groups.
population_specificity: Middle-aged men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of protein supplementation (whey isolate and beef hydrolysate) on gut microbiota balance in cross-country runners.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Maltodextrin's effects.
population_specificity: Cross-country runners

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of maltodextrin (control) against whey protein supplementation on nutritional status, immunity, and inflammatory markers in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a control and showed significantly lower improvements in glutathione levels (6.0%) compared to the whey protein group (11.7%). No other specific effects of maltodextrin were highlighted.
population_specificity: 42 cancer patients (41-63 years old) receiving intravenous chemotherapy in Thailand.
effective_dosage: Maltodextrin oral snack daily (exact amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) versus taurine on repeated sprint exercise performance and physiological responses.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed higher peak sprint power compared to taurine during repeated sprints, but no direct effects of maltodextrin itself were reported. The study primarily focused on taurine's effects, with maltodextrin serving as a control.
population_specificity: Nine females

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of β2-1 fructan and maltodextrin on fecal bacterial communities and host parameters in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin did not significantly alter fecal bacterial communities, metagenome, or glycoside hydrolase profiles, and no defined health benefits were observed for β2-1 fructans or maltodextrin in healthy subjects.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (n=30)
study_duration: 28 days per treatment, with a 14-day washout between treatments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate maltodextrin as a control substance in comparison to activated and micronized zeolites and vitamin E for modulating oxidative stress in smokers.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a control and showed no significant antioxidant activity compared to activated and micronized zeolites or vitamin E, which had equivalent antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: Mexican smokers without lung diseases

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of resistant dextrin (Nutriose) on immune-mediated inflammation and hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis activity in women with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Resistant dextrin significantly reduced cortisol, inflammatory markers (IFNγ, IL12, LPS), and stress indicators (GHQ, DASS), while increasing anti-inflammatory markers (IL10, IL4) and immune cell activity (CD8). No significant changes were observed in white blood cell count, CD4, or other measured cytokines.
population_specificity: Females with type 2 diabetes mellitus (n=55, intervention group n=30, control group n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a whey protein supplement versus maltodextrin on chronic inflammation, body composition, and insulin resistance.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding maltodextrin's effects, only mentioning the study's focus on comparing it with whey protein.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of fermented Maillard-reactive whey protein (F-MRP) to maltodextrin (placebo) on NK cell activity, cytokines, and serum protein levels.
results_summary: The placebo group (maltodextrin) showed significant reductions in NK cell activity, serum albumin, and pre-albumin compared to baseline, while the F-MRP group showed improvements. Maltodextrin did not enhance immune or metabolic markers.
population_specificity: 80 participants without diabetes or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of prebiotic supplementation (oligofructose, not maltodextrin) on metabolic endotoxemia and systemic inflammation in adults with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: Oligofructose reduced plasma LPS concentrations by 40% and PAI-1 levels more than placebo, but did not affect other inflammatory markers like IL-6 or TNF-α.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight and obesity (BMI 30.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 21 g of oligofructose (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of l-arginine supplementation versus placebo (maltodextrin) on sport performance and body composition in male soccer players.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed no significant effects on sport performance or body composition (BMI, BFM, LBM) compared to l-arginine. The study concluded that maltodextrin did not influence the measured outcomes.
population_specificity: 56 male soccer players aged 16-35 from sport clubs in Isfahan, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a prebiotic (galacto-oligosaccharide mixture) versus a placebo (maltodextrin) on intestinal microbiota, glucose tolerance, and related markers in men with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Maltodextrin as a placebo showed no significant effects on clinical outcomes, bacterial abundances, or microbial community structure compared to the prebiotic. Changes in bacterial family Veillonellaceae correlated with glucose response and IL-6 levels, but these were not attributed to maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Twenty-nine men with well-controlled type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a multi-ingredient performance supplement (MIPS) containing Maltodextrin on inflammation, muscle damage, soreness, and performance in endurance-trained female athletes after downhill running.
results_summary: The study found that MIPS attenuated inflammation three days post-exercise but did not significantly affect perceived soreness or muscle damage markers. Lower limb performance and circumferences were also unaffected.
population_specificity: Endurance-trained female runners.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of carbohydrate (Maltodextrin) supplementation on cytokines and cellular damage markers after exercise under hypoxic conditions.
results_summary: Carbohydrate supplementation modified IL-6 and TNF-α serum concentrations and shifted the IL-2/IL-4 balance towards Th1 without affecting glycemic levels, glutaminemia, or cell damage markers.
population_specificity: Seven adult male volunteers exercising at 50% VO₂ max under hypoxic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of pre-exercise and post-exercise creatine supplementation on aging bone mineral content (BMC) and density (BMD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Aging adults (mean age 53 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: Not available (abstract mentions creatine dosage but not Maltodextrin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of creatine supplementation combined with maltodextrin versus maltodextrin alone during drop-set resistance training in untrained aging adults.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin was used as a placebo and did not significantly enhance muscle mass, strength, or endurance compared to creatine supplementation. Drop-set resistance training alone improved muscle metrics, but maltodextrin did not provide additional benefits beyond those seen with training.
population_specificity: Untrained aging adults (mean age ~58 years, mixed gender).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multimodal perioperative protocol, including preoperative maltodextrin, could reduce length of stay and postoperative acute phase response in hip arthroplasty patients.
results_summary: The ACERTO group, which included maltodextrin, had a significantly shorter median hospital stay (3 vs. 6 days) and lower postoperative CRP levels compared to the control group. No adverse events or complications were reported.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (mean age 58 years, range 26-85, 16 males).
effective_dosage: 200 mL of 12.5% maltodextrin up to 2 hours before anesthesia induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin versus increased protein intake on renal function, blood pressure, and related parameters in overweight individuals with elevated blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin intake did not significantly affect renal function, blood pressure, or related parameters compared to protein intake, except for a lower postprandial filtration fraction in the protein group. No adverse effects on kidney function were observed with maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Overweight individuals with untreated elevated blood pressure and normal kidney function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin supplementation versus whey protein on body composition and performance measures in female athletes.
results_summary: The maltodextrin group showed a non-significant trend in lean mass gain (+0.4 kg) and no significant fat mass loss (-0.5 kg). Performance improvements in leg press 1RM, vertical jump, and broad jump were similar to the whey protein group, but maltodextrin did not significantly improve agility or bench press 1RM compared to whey protein.
population_specificity: NCAA Division III female basketball players (n=6 in maltodextrin group).
effective_dosage: 24 g immediately prior to and following training (4 days/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of β2-1 fructan supplementation versus placebo (maltodextrin) on gut microbiota, immune function, and general health in healthy adults.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (placebo) showed no significant effects on blood lipids, cholesterol, immune markers, or well-being compared to β2-1 fructan. No adverse effects specific to maltodextrin were reported, though GI symptoms and headaches increased during the β2-1 fructan phase.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (13 men, 17 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin, whey protein, and their combination on body composition, muscle strength, and cardiovascular health markers in response to resistance training.
results_summary: Maltodextrin supplementation did not significantly differ from whey protein or combined supplementation in increasing fat-free mass, muscle size, or strength. However, whey protein led to greater abdominal fat loss and relative fat-free mass gains compared to maltodextrin. No significant effects on serum lipids were observed.
population_specificity: Previously untrained males
effective_dosage: Isocaloric carbohydrates (maltodextrin), exact dosage not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a bolus ingestion of creatine (compared to maltodextrin placebo) consumed 3 hours before resistance exercise affects muscle performance in aging males.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in muscle performance (leg press and chest press repetitions to fatigue) between creatine and maltodextrin placebo conditions, suggesting maltodextrin had no effect on exercise outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy aging males (N = 9, 54.8 ± 4.3 years).
study_duration: Single administration (7 days apart from creatine condition).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a nonnitrogenous control) against a protein supplement on lean tissue mass preservation in older adults.
results_summary: Maltodextrin supplementation resulted in a slight decrease in lean tissue mass (-0.16 kg) compared to the protein group, which showed an increase (+0.45 kg). The study concluded that maltodextrin did not support lean tissue mass preservation as effectively as protein supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 50-70 years (mean age 61 ± 5 years).
effective_dosage: Isoenergetic maltodextrin control administered at breakfast and midday meals (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological mechanisms by which carbohydrate (including maltodextrin) impacts intermittent sport performance and derive recommendations for carbohydrate intake before/during exercise.
results_summary: Carbohydrate ingestion (including maltodextrin) at ~30-60 g/h enhanced intermittent high-intensity exercise capacity in most studies, but effects on sprinting, jumping, skill, change of direction speed, and cognition were mixed. The greatest performance impact occurred under conditions eliciting fatigue or hypoglycemia, particularly towards the end of a game.
population_specificity: Athletes in intermittent sports (e.g., soccer, rugby, field hockey, basketball, American football, racquet sports).
effective_dosage: ~30-60 g/h in a 6%-7% carbohydrate solution (sucrose, glucose, and/or maltodextrin).
study_duration: Not specified (acute effects during ~1-2 h of exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the timing of creatine supplementation (before or after resistance training) influenced its effectiveness in improving muscle mass and strength in older adults, using maltodextrin as a placebo.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin, used as a placebo, did not significantly improve lean tissue mass or muscle strength compared to creatine supplementation. Creatine supplementation, regardless of timing, increased muscle strength more than placebo, with post-exercise creatine showing greater gains in lean tissue mass.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 50-71 years.
effective_dosage: 0.1 g/kg cornstarch maltodextrin (placebo) administered immediately before or after resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of glucomannan (GNN) compared to placebo (maltodextrin) for weight management in overweight or obese children.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding maltodextrin's effects, as the study is described as a planned trial without reported outcomes.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-17 years who are overweight or obese based on WHO growth criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistant dextrin and maltodextrin (as placebo) on insulin resistance and inflammation in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Maltodextrin, used as a placebo, showed no significant improvements in fasting plasma glucose, HbA1c, or hs-CRP compared to resistant dextrin. The study found no significant adverse effects from maltodextrin, but it was not the primary focus of the investigation.
population_specificity: Fifty-five women with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein and maltodextrin (placebo) on muscle mass and strength gains during resistance training in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Maltodextrin, used as a placebo, showed no significant difference compared to whey protein in improving muscle strength or thickness, suggesting it did not enhance training outcomes. Both groups showed similar improvements in muscle strength and thickness over time.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women (n=12; age 57 ± 4.7 years).
effective_dosage: 4 x 10 gram aliquots per training session (2 days per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of microencapsulated creatine monohydrate versus maltodextrin (placebo) on plasma creatine concentrations in physically active males.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (placebo) showed no change in plasma creatine concentrations, while microencapsulated creatine significantly increased levels, peaking at 30 minutes and remaining elevated for 3 hours. The study did not report any specific effects or adverse outcomes related to maltodextrin itself.
population_specificity: Ten physically active male volunteers.
study_duration: Single ingestion with measurements taken over 3 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maltodextrin (as a placebo) had any effect on correcting muscle hypercatabolism in the unaffected arm of dysphagic subacute stroke patients compared to essential amino acid supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin did not correct muscle hypercatabolism in stroke patients, unlike the essential amino acid group, which showed improved protein turnover or anabolic activity after 38 days. The placebo group's muscle hypercatabolism rates remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Dysphagic subacute stroke patients (<3 months post-stroke, 29 males and 9 females, average age 69.7±11.4 years).
effective_dosage: Isocaloric placebo (exact dosage not specified, but matched to 8 g/day EAAs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (control) with two doses of a dietary fiber combination (OFS + P) on energy intake and glycemic parameters.
results_summary: Maltodextrin showed no significant reduction in energy intake compared to the fiber groups, with a slight non-significant decrease (-9.0 kcal). The study found no statistically significant differences in energy intake among the groups.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese, otherwise healthy subjects (N=96).

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of XOS, Bi-07, and their combination (synbiotic) against maltodextrin supplementation to assess changes in bowel habits, mood, gut microbiota, blood lipids, and immune function.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a control and did not show significant changes in bowel habits, mood, or immune markers compared to the active interventions. No adverse effects were reported for maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 25-65 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified for maltodextrin (used as control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Maltodextrin (used as a placebo) had any effect on antibody concentrations after DTaP-IPV-Hib immunization in preterm infants compared to a prebiotic supplement.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in antibody concentrations between the Maltodextrin (placebo) group and the prebiotic group at 5 and 12 months, indicating Maltodextrin did not enhance or impair immunization response.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age <32 weeks and/or birth weight <1500 g.
study_duration: Administered between days 3 and 30 of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of maltodextrin (as a placebo) on cytokine levels in preterm infants compared to a non-digestible carbohydrate mixture.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and did not show a significant effect on cytokine levels, unlike the active intervention which temporarily reduced cytokine levels at day 7. Cytokine levels in the placebo group followed a natural increase during the neonatal period and decreased later.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (gestational age <32 weeks and/or birth weight <1500 g).
study_duration: Administered between days 3 and 30 of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo control) against soy and whey protein supplementation on sex hormone responses following heavy resistance exercise in resistance-trained men.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo control and showed no significant effects on testosterone, cortisol, or estradiol levels compared to soy or whey protein. The study primarily focused on the hormonal impacts of soy and whey, with maltodextrin serving as a neutral baseline.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained men (age 21.7 ± 2.8 years, height 175.0 ± 5.4 cm, weight 84.2 ± 9.1 kg).
effective_dosage: 20 g per day, ingested each morning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sodium bicarbonate (SB) supplementation versus maltodextrin (PLA) on 2000-m rowing performance.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of SB over maltodextrin using paired t tests, but magnitude-based inferences suggested a likely beneficial effect of SB, particularly in the latter half of the rowing event. Maltodextrin served as a placebo and showed no performance-enhancing effects.
population_specificity: Twenty male rowers (age 23 ± 4 y, height 1.85 ± 0.08 m, mass 82.5 ± 8.9 kg).
study_duration: Single dose administered before each of two 2000-m rowing trials, separated by 48 h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term protective effects of a prebiotic-supplemented formula (scGOS/lcFOS) versus a placebo (maltodextrin) on allergic manifestations in high-risk infants.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin (placebo) was associated with significantly higher cumulative incidences of allergic manifestations, including atopic dermatitis and allergic rhinoconjunctivitis, compared to the prebiotic group. No significant difference was observed for recurrent wheezing.
population_specificity: Healthy term infants at risk of atopy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a control) against a synbiotic supplement on stool consistency and intestinal transit time in patients with severe functional constipation.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (Group B) did not show a statistically significant improvement in stool consistency or reduction in intestinal transit time compared to the synbiotic supplement (Group A). The study found no notable benefits of maltodextrin for functional constipation.
population_specificity: Patients with severe functional constipation fulfilling the Rome III Diagnostic Criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of creatine supplementation versus maltodextrin (placebo) combined with resistance training on strength, functional performance, and body composition in older women.
results_summary: The maltodextrin (placebo) group showed no significant changes in body mass or % body fat and had lesser improvements in strength, functional performance, and muscle mass compared to the creatine group.
population_specificity: Healthy older women (64.9 ± 5.0 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the postprandial sympathetic and hemodynamic responses after high-carbohydrate (HC) meals containing maltodextrin versus high-protein (HP) meals in individuals with elevated blood pressure.
results_summary: On day 1, maltodextrin (HC) meals led to a greater decrease in mean arterial pressure (MAP) compared to HP meals, but this difference disappeared after 4 weeks due to a more pronounced decrease in MAP in the HP group. Postprandial total peripheral resistance tended to decrease more in the HC group, and cardiac output tended to increase more in the HC group after 4 weeks.
population_specificity: 52 men and women with untreated elevated blood pressure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) versus creatine supplementation on functional capacity in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in functional capacity (measured by cardiopulmonary exercise test and 6-minute walk test) between the maltodextrin (placebo) and creatine groups, indicating maltodextrin had no measurable impact on outcomes.
population_specificity: Male patients over 18 years with functional class II to IV heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how energy gain from resistant maltodextrin consumption varies based on gut microbiota composition and its adaptation over time.
results_summary: Resistant maltodextrin supplementation increased total faecal bacteria and beneficial bifidobacteria, with energy gain dependent on individual microbiota composition and adaptation. The study also identified microbiota signatures linked to early risk markers for colorectal carcinogenesis.
population_specificity: Adults in a controlled feeding trial, pre-term infants, and elderly adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maltodextrin as a placebo compared to resveratrol-enriched grape extract and grape extract alone on cardiovascular markers in statin-treated patients.
results_summary: The study found no changes in LDL cholesterol, ApoB, LDLox, or other atherogenic markers in the maltodextrin (placebo) group after 6 months of supplementation. No adverse effects were observed in any patients.
population_specificity: Statin-treated patients in primary cardiovascular disease prevention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of maltodextrin supplementation on exercise-induced hormone responses and post-training intramyocellular lipid stores in elite athletes.
results_summary: Maltodextrin supplementation increased intramyocellular lipid stores in the tibialis anterior muscle, elevated insulin levels, reduced free fatty acids and growth hormone levels, and attenuated performance decline during high-intensity running compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 24 elite male athletes (28.0±1.2 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of short-term galactose supplementation versus a glucose-maltodextrin equivalent on endurance cycling performance.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in overall 100-km performance time between galactose and glucose-maltodextrin, but galactose may improve intermediate self-paced efforts. Mean power output and heart rate were similar between the two carbohydrate types.
population_specificity: Highly trained endurance cyclists
effective_dosage: 38±3 g pre-exercise and 37±3 g/hr during exercise in a 6% concentrate fluid form

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) against creatine monohydrate on anaerobic performance, strength, and body weight.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in peak power, body weight, or strength (1RM leg extension and bench press) in the maltodextrin group, indicating it had no measurable effect on these outcomes compared to baseline.
population_specificity: 22 healthy men (mean age 22.1 ± 2.0 years, body weight 77.6 ± 7.6 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin supplementation versus whey protein on body composition and physical function in older women during weight loss.
results_summary: Maltodextrin supplementation resulted in less weight loss and less reduction in muscle, subcutaneous adipose tissue, and intermuscular adipose tissue compared to whey protein. However, changes in lean soft tissue, strength, balance, and physical performance did not differ significantly between the groups.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese postmenopausal women (mean age 65.2 ± 4.6 years, BMI 33.7 ± 4.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of oligofructose and maltodextrin (placebo) on appetite profiles, satiety hormone concentrations, and energy intake in healthy human subjects.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed no significant effects on energy intake or satiety hormone concentrations compared to oligofructose, which demonstrated efficacy in reducing energy intake and increasing GLP-1 and PYY levels.
population_specificity: Thirty-one healthy subjects (10 men, 21 women) aged 28 ± 3 years with a BMI of 24.8 ± 0.3 kg/m².
study_duration: 13 days per treatment period, with a 2-week washout between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a prebiotic mixture versus maltodextrin (placebo) on fecal bifidobacteria and lactobacilli counts in newborns.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (placebo) showed no significant increase in fecal bifidobacteria or lactobacilli compared to the prebiotic group, with no influence on anthropometric or immunological variables.
population_specificity: Newborns of hepatitis C virus-infected mothers who did not breastfeed.
study_duration: Administered from birth until at least 6 months, with follow-up until 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether maltodextrin supplementation could mitigate markers of training-induced tissue damage and inflammation in long-distance runners undergoing intensive training.
results_summary: Maltodextrin ingestion attenuated increases in free plasma DNA, LDH levels, and leukocyte counts post-exercise, suggesting reduced DNA damage and inflammation compared to the control group. The CHO group also showed better recovery markers following high-intensity intermittent running.
population_specificity: 24 male long-distance runners
effective_dosage: Not specified (maltodextrin solution administered before, during, and after the high-intensity protocol)
study_duration: 9 days (8 days of overload training + 1 day of high-intensity intermittent running)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) against PEG-creatine supplementation on strength and power measures in untrained men.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in lower body strength (1RMLE), mean power, peak power, or body weight for the maltodextrin group, indicating it had no measurable effect on these outcomes compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Untrained men (mean age 22.1 ± 2.1 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maltodextrin (used as a placebo) had any effect on intestinal inflammation markers (fecal IL-8 and calprotectin) in preterm infants compared to prebiotic supplementation.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of maltodextrin (placebo) on fecal IL-8 or calprotectin levels in preterm infants, with no difference observed between the placebo and prebiotic groups. The markers were strongly correlated but unaffected by the intervention.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age <32 weeks and/or birth weight <1,500 g.
study_duration: Administered between day 3 and day 30 of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a prebiotic mixture (scGOS/lcFOS/pAOS) against maltodextrin (placebo) on stool viscosity, frequency, and pH in preterm infants.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (placebo) resulted in higher stool viscosity and pH compared to the prebiotic group, with no significant difference in stool frequency. The study concluded that maltodextrin did not offer specific advantages over the prebiotic mixture.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age <32 weeks and/or birth weight <1500 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enteral supplementation with a prebiotic mixture (SCGOS/LCFOS/AOS) compared to placebo (maltodextrin) affects intestinal permeability in preterm infants during the first week of life.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of the prebiotic mixture (or maltodextrin placebo) on intestinal permeability, as measured by the lactulose/mannitol ratio. Both groups showed a similar decrease in permeability over time, influenced by birth weight and feeding type.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age < 32 weeks and/or birth weight < 1500 g.
study_duration: Administered between days 3 and 30 of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enteral supplementation of a prebiotic mixture (including maltodextrin as a placebo) affected serious infectious morbidity in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in serious infectious morbidity between the prebiotic-supplemented and maltodextrin placebo groups, though there was a trend toward fewer serious endogenous infections in the prebiotic group. Maltodextrin was used as a neutral comparator without reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (gestational age <32 weeks and/or birth weight <1500 g).
effective_dosage: 1.5 g/kg/day (as part of the placebo formulation).
study_duration: Administered between days 3 and 30 of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel mRNA nanovaccine (HM@Mn3O4-mRNA) using Mn3O4 encapsulation for enhancing cancer immunotherapy.
results_summary: The nanovaccine effectively targeted dendritic cells, enhanced antigen expression, and triggered a strong T cell-mediated immune response, preventing and controlling B16-OVA subcutaneous tumors in vivo.
population_specificity: B16-OVA subcutaneous tumor model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manganese-rich nanoplatforms (TPP-MMONs) could enhance antitumor immunity in triple-negative breast cancer by inducing mitochondrial dysfunction and activating the cGAS-STING pathway.
results_summary: The study found that TPP-MMONs released Mn²⁺, induced mitochondrial dysfunction, and triggered mtDNA release, effectively activating the cGAS-STING pathway. This enhanced immune responses and improved the efficacy of αPD-L1 therapy in suppressing tumor growth in localized and metastatic models.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (4T1 tumor model in mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel nano system combining sonodynamics and immunotherapy using manganese phycocyanin nanoparticles for targeted treatment of cutaneous melanoma.
results_summary: Mn-PCNP-LMS@CM effectively targeted melanoma, enhanced reactive oxygen species generation under ultrasound, improved sonodynamic therapy outcomes, and promoted immune response, preventing tumor growth and recurrence.
population_specificity: Cutaneous melanoma (B16-OVA cell model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of manganese-based nanotherapeutics for breast cancer treatment, focusing on their multifunctional applications in modulating the tumor microenvironment and imaging-guided therapy.
results_summary: The study highlighted manganese-based nanotherapeutics' versatility, biodegradability, and biocompatibility, demonstrating their effectiveness in modulating the tumor microenvironment, enhancing imaging techniques, and serving as therapeutic carriers for breast cancer.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (specific demographic details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether maltodextrin, when used as a placebo, had any effect on markers of muscle damage compared to creatine supplementation in athletes and rats undergoing strenuous activity.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin alone (placebo group) did not prevent increases in plasma markers of muscle damage (CK, LDH, ALD, GOT, GPT, CRP) post-competition in athletes, while creatine supplementation showed protective effects. In rats, maltodextrin was not directly evaluated for efficacy, as the focus was on creatine's effects.
population_specificity: Ironman triathletes (n=8) and rats subjected to electrical stimulation-induced strenuous contractile activity.
effective_dosage: 50 g/day divided into two equal doses (human study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a manganese-based nanoadjuvant (BMP-Au) could enhance anti-tumor immune responses in breast cancer therapy by inducing immunogenic cell death and activating the cGAS-STING pathway.
results_summary: BMP-Au demonstrated efficacy in generating reactive oxygen species, initiating disulfidptosis, and activating the cGAS-STING pathway, thereby enhancing tumor immunogenicity and compromising cancer cell viability. The nanoadjuvant leveraged both cellular stress mechanisms and immune activation for improved anti-tumor effects.
population_specificity: Breast cancer (specific patient population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine associations between prenatal urinary manganese (Mn) levels and sleep outcomes in children, exploring potential sex-specific effects.
results_summary: Higher prenatal Mn levels were associated with reduced sleep duration and efficiency, particularly in males, while low Mn levels were linked to increased wake after sleep onset and decreased sleep efficiency. The study suggests Mn levels, whether insufficient or excessive, may disrupt sleep neuroarchitecture.
population_specificity: Children aged 6.7±2.0 years and their mothers (prenatal urinary Mn levels assessed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (urinary Mn levels analyzed by tertiles: low, moderate, high).
study_duration: Not specified (prenatal exposure assessed, child sleep outcomes measured at ~6.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the neurologic outcome following BMX-001 treatment in a mouse intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) model, with relevance to prospective ischemic stroke clinical trials.
results_summary: BMX-001 reduced the number of macrophages and cells stained with Prussian blue (indicating iron release) in the hemorrhagic area, suggesting an anti-inflammatory effect, but no significant differences were found in body weight, neurological deficits, or hemorrhage size between groups.
population_specificity: C57Bl6 mice with induced intracerebral hemorrhage.
study_duration: Treatment was administered immediately post-surgery, with evaluation at 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rGOQD/MnO2/GOx/CPP nanoparticles in enhancing chemodynamic/photothermal therapy (CDT/PTT) and starvation therapy (ST) for targeted cancer treatment.
results_summary: The nanoparticles effectively inhibited tumor growth by generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) via MnO2, depleting glutathione (GSH), and inducing glucose starvation, while near-infrared (NIR) irradiation enhanced photothermal therapy without adverse effects.
population_specificity: U87 glioblastoma cells (in vitro) and nude mice bearing subcutaneous U87 tumors (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Mn transporters, Mn-related neurotoxicity, and inherited/acquired disorders of Mn metabolism, including available treatments.
results_summary: Mn is essential but chronic overexposure can cause manganism, resembling Parkinson's disease. Inherited Mn metabolism disorders (e.g., SLC30A10, SLC39A14 mutations) require early treatment for better prognosis.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize mechanistic research exploring the association between manganese exposure and Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology.
results_summary: The study found that manganese exposure contributes to AD through mechanisms like glutamate excitotoxicity and dopamine neuron damage, intersecting with known AD pathways such as oxidative stress and neuroinflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population exposed to environmental manganese).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a manganese-doped bimetallic MOF for precise ROS/RNS scavenging and osteogenic regulation to protect stem cells from oxidative stress.
results_summary: The manganese-doped MOF enhanced catalase-like activity for ROS degradation, preserved stem cell viability and function, and promoted osteogenic differentiation with sustained Dex release.
population_specificity: Bone mesenchymal stem cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining manganese (Mn²+) and bisphosphonates (BPs) could synergistically enhance immunogenic cell death (ICD) and improve the efficacy of anti-PD-L1 therapy in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
results_summary: MnHARis particles, a combination of Mn²+ and risedronate, demonstrated a synergistic antitumor effect by increasing cytotoxicity, inducing mitochondrial autophagic apoptosis, and promoting ICD, which sensitized TNBC to anti-PD-L1 therapy. The mechanism involved the p38-MAPK pathway and enhanced dendritic cell activation.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) models (4T1 tumor models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel manganese-based metal-organic framework (Mn-MOF) composite for selectively removing Pb2+ from wastewater.
results_summary: The Mn-MOF composite (MFCys) demonstrated superior and rapid adsorption of Pb2+, reaching equilibrium within 2 hours, with high selectivity and reusability, retaining 98.0% of its initial adsorption capacity after five cycles. It also performed exceptionally well in simulated lead-acid battery wastewater.
population_specificity: Simulated lead-acid battery wastewater (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (material synthesis and adsorption conditions described, but no dosage per se).
study_duration: Adsorption equilibrium reached within 2 hours; reusability tested over five cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a scalable synthesis method for lithium manganese oxides (LMO) to improve lithium extraction efficiency and selectivity from brines, while reducing manganese dissolution.
results_summary: The novel spray drying method enabled scalable LMO synthesis with improved lithium selectivity and extraction capabilities. Substituting Mn with Ti reduced manganese dissolution during acid treatment and increased sorption capacity.
population_specificity: Synthetic LiCl solutions and geothermal brines from the Upper Rhine valley.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a nanoparticle (PMMF) delivering manganese and a HIF-2α antagonist (PT2385) for targeting pVHL-deficient tumors.
results_summary: PMMF effectively targeted pVHL-deficient tumors, alleviated hypoxic and immunosuppressive traits, and stimulated an innate immune response via NK cells and CD8+ T lymphocytes, with minimal systemic cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: pVHL-deficient clear-cell renal cell carcinoma and melanoma models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms of manganese (Mn)-induced motor disease and identify potential treatments by studying its effects on metabolic pathways.
results_summary: Mn exposure upregulated the kynurenine pathway in the brain and liver, leading to motor deficits, which were rescued by pharmacological inhibition of this pathway. Mn also activated HIF1, contributing to kynurenine pathway dysregulation.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model of human environmental Mn exposure)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manganese dioxide (MnO2) nanoparticles synergize with gambogic acid to enhance anti-tumor efficacy and modulate the tumor microenvironment in colorectal cancer.
results_summary: MBG NPs demonstrated significant cytotoxicity against CT26 cells, reduced tumor volumes in mice, and improved survival rates, with enhanced effects when combined with aPD-1. Mn2+ ions from MnO2 alleviated tumor hypoxia and modulated the immune response.
population_specificity: Mouse colon cancer cells (CT26 cells) and BALB/c mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of manganese-based materials in MRI-guided anticancer theranostic applications, focusing on their dual-modal MR-relaxation, therapeutic capabilities, and safety.
results_summary: The study highlights manganese's effectiveness in MRI-guided therapies, including chemodynamic therapy, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy, due to its T1/T2 dual-modal properties and low toxicity. It also discusses stimulus-based probes (e.g., pH, temperature) to explore further applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a synbiotic supplement versus maltodextrin (placebo) on gastrointestinal function in chronically constipated women.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (placebo) showed no significant improvement in evacuation frequency, stool consistency, or constipation intensity compared to the synbiotic group, though abdominal symptoms were similarly unaffected in both groups.
population_specificity: 100 chronically constipated adult women diagnosed by ROME III criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the degradation of sulfonamides by biogenic manganese oxides (BioMnOx) and manganese-oxidizing bacteria (MnOB) in the presence of a redox mediator (syringaldehyde).
results_summary: Initial degradation of sulfonamides was poor, but syringaldehyde increased degradation efficiency by 26-58%. BioMnOx and MnOB synergistically improved degradation, though removal was partially reversible due to unstable reaction products.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas putida MnB6 (bacterial strain) and biogenic manganese oxides in a controlled batch system.
interactions: Syringaldehyde (a redox mediator) influenced degradation and reversibility of reaction products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mn2+ modification of nanoparticles (C-SMNPs) could enhance the activation of cGAS-STING signaling and improve immune response in HNSCC when combined with ICB therapy.
results_summary: Mn2+ modification (C-SMNPs) enhanced cGAS-STING signaling, boosted DC maturation and cytotoxic T-cell differentiation, and resulted in more sustained tumor suppression when combined with ICB compared to non-Mn2+ nanoparticles (C-SNPs).
population_specificity: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a multifunctional DNA-templated manganese carbonate nanoparticle (DtMnP) for tumor diagnostics and treatment, addressing the challenge of insufficient intracellular metal cofactors for DNAzyme activation.
results_summary: The DtMnP exhibited pH-responsive Mn2+ release (90% within 60 min at pH 5.5), enabling superior MRI contrast and synergistic therapeutic efficacy through DNAzyme-mediated gene silencing (60% mRNA downregulation) and Mn2+-catalyzed Fenton reactions (45% apoptosis in MCF-7 cells).
population_specificity: MCF-7 xenograft models (breast cancer cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how manganese carbonate-modified carbonaceous materials derived from agricultural waste could effectively degrade pharmaceutical compounds via singlet oxygen production.
results_summary: Manganese carbonate-modified materials demonstrated significant efficiency in degrading organic molecules, with singlet oxygen as the primary oxidant. Computational approaches helped understand the interaction between materials and molecules, and carbonate ions were found to influence singlet oxygen production.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using pharmaceutical compounds as targets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how integrating nanoparticulate manganese dioxide (MnO2) into a ferric oxide (Fe2O3) framework affects catalytic performance, stability, and pollutant degradation efficiency.
results_summary: The composite structure showed near-complete BPA mineralization under UV irradiation due to synergistic radical and nonradical mechanisms, with MnFe-12 reducing Mn leaching by 2200-fold compared to bare MnO2. The Fe2O3 matrix enhanced structural stability, and in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy revealed Mn oxidation state changes during radical-mediated processes.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro/environmental study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the structural, magnetic, and hyperthermic properties of manganese-doped magnetic nanoflowers (Mn-NFs) for potential use in lung cancer therapy via magnetic hyperthermia.
results_summary: Mn-NFs exhibited enhanced magnetic properties and high heating efficiency, with optimal biocompatibility and cellular uptake at x = 0.3 Mn content, leading to significant cancer cell death under alternating magnetic fields.
population_specificity: A549 lung carcinoma cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: MnxFe3-xO4 (x = 0, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7) nanoparticle concentrations tested under varying AMF intensities.
study_duration: Not specified (in vitro exposure duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a manganese-ion-encapsulated peptide hydrogel-based nanovaccine could effectively stimulate immune responses against gastric cancer.
results_summary: The nanovaccine successfully activated immune responses via TLR9 and cGAS-STING pathways, enhancing antigen recognition and response in gastric cancer models. The sustained release system demonstrated robust and clinically relevant immune activation.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a composite cementitious material using industrial solid wastes (including electrolytic manganese residue) and evaluate its mechanical properties, hydration mechanisms, and environmental safety.
results_summary: The composite material achieved a compressive strength of 27.9 MPa and flexural strength of 7.5 MPa at 28 days, with hydration products (ettringite and C-S-H) contributing to its mechanical strength. Leaching tests confirmed heavy metal concentrations within safe limits per drinking water standards.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study).
effective_dosage: Optimal composition: 20% EMR, 15% RM, 52% GGBS, 13% Ca(OH)₂, water-binder ratio of 0.5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between manganese exposure, trace element dysregulation, and cognitive function, as well as the potential of curcumin to mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Manganese exposure impaired learning, memory, and balance in rats, disrupted elemental homeostasis in multiple tissues, and hippocampal dysregulation correlated with cognitive decline. Curcumin intervention improved behavioral abnormalities and partially restored elemental balance.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether macrophage membrane-coated manganese dioxide nanospheres loaded with rapamycin (Ma@(MnO₂+RAPA)) could alleviate intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury by reducing oxidative stress, promoting autophagy, and inhibiting inflammation.
results_summary: Ma@(MnO₂+RAPA) effectively reduced ROS, increased oxygen levels, inhibited inflammation, and promoted autophagy while reducing apoptosis in IEC-6 cells and significantly improved outcomes in a mouse I/R model, including reduced oxidative stress and enhanced autophagy-regulated protein expression.
population_specificity: In vitro IEC-6 cells and in vivo mouse models of intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of manganese(ii) texaphyrin (MMn) in dynamically sensing peroxynitrite (ONOO-) and tracking epileptic seizures in real-time using photoacoustic imaging.
results_summary: MMn demonstrated preferential sensitivity to ONOO- over other reactive oxygen species, successfully crossed the blood-brain barrier, and provided observable reductions in photoacoustic signal intensity during epileptic seizures, mirroring seizure activity in mice.
population_specificity: Pentylenetetrazole (PTZ)-induced epilepsy mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanocomplex (PMB NPs) using manganese (Mn) ions to enhance cGAS-STING signaling and eradicate cancer stem cells (CSCs) for improved immunotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
results_summary: The study found that PMB NPs released Mn ions in acidic tumor microenvironments, significantly enhancing cGAS-STING signals and dendritic cell maturation, while PTC209 targeted CSCs to suppress cancer stemness and metastasis, synergizing with Mn-based metalloimmunotherapy to bolster anti-PD-1 therapy.
population_specificity: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of manganese-ferric Prussian blue nanozymes on ischemic stroke, focusing on gut microbiota balance and neuroinflammation.
results_summary: The nanozymes reduced infarct volume, improved neurological function, restored gut microbiota balance, and increased short-chain fatty acid levels by modulating the Toll-like receptor 4/nuclear factor kappa B signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Mouse model of middle cerebral artery occlusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of single-atom manganese-doped carbon dots (SA Mn-CDs) for tumor catalytic therapy, focusing on their peroxidase-like activity and targeting capabilities.
results_summary: SA Mn-CDs demonstrated excellent biological safety, stability, deep-level two-photon fluorescence imaging, and lysosome-targeting ability. They showed high-efficiency peroxidase-like activity, effectively killing tumor cells and shrinking tumor tissues in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Tumor cells and tissues (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficiency and mechanistic differences between RMnS (reactive manganese species) and ETP (electron transfer process) in activating potassium permanganate for water remediation.
results_summary: RMnS demonstrated higher degradation efficiency and stronger dehalogenation capacity for bromophenols compared to ETP, reducing brominated disinfection byproducts formation potential (DBPFPs). ETP showed superior degradation efficiency in real water backgrounds and lower energy consumption.
population_specificity: Water treatment processes (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biomedical applications of Mn-based materials, focusing on their catalytic properties, structural designs, and therapeutic potential for antitumor and antibacterial therapy.
results_summary: The study found that Mn-based nanoenzymes exhibit remarkable catalytic activity, biodegradability, and low toxicity, making them effective for antitumor and antibacterial applications. Different structural designs, such as nanoparticles and nanotubes, enhance their therapeutic efficacy, including ROS generation and tumor tissue penetration.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of preclinical and potential clinical applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanical properties of medium manganese steel and the effects of aluminium and manganese on its microstructure, focusing on achieving high tensile strength and elongation.
results_summary: The study achieved a tensile strength of 1262 ± 6 MPa and elongation of 16 ± 1%, exceeding the anticipated UTS but falling short of the expected elongation range. The microstructure incorporated residual austenite as intended.
population_specificity: Medium manganese steel sheets (0.2% carbon, 3% manganese, 2.15% aluminium by weight).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (material composition: 3% manganese by weight).
study_duration: Not specified (intercritical annealing parameters were the focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manganese dioxide nanoparticles (Tuf-Rif@HA-MnO2 NPs) could synergistically enhance macrophage-targeted drug delivery and activate cGAS-STING signaling for improved anti-TB immunotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that Tuf-Rif@HA-MnO2 NPs effectively targeted macrophages, released Mn2+ to activate cGAS-STING signaling, promoted autophagy and M1 polarization, and enhanced immune cell activation, leading to reduced Mtb burdens and alleviated lung inflammation in mice without systemic toxicity.
population_specificity: Mycobacterium tuberculosis-infected mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hyaluronic acid microneedles loaded with zinc-manganese sulfide and Sparfloxacin in enhancing antitumor immune responses and preventing postoperative recurrence in triple-negative breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that the microneedles activated the cGAS-STING pathway, suppressed tumor growth, reduced lung metastasis, promoted wound healing, and increased immune cell infiltration. The treatment also demonstrated strong antimicrobial and antibiofilm properties.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients undergoing postoperative treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the roles and mechanisms of Manganese in tumor biology and assess the potential of Mn-based nanomaterials in cancer diagnosis and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that Mn-based nanomaterials show promise in enhancing conventional and emerging cancer therapies, including immunotherapy and photodynamic therapy, and can improve diagnostic precision and combined treatment capabilities.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on tumor biology and applications in cancer treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron-manganese oxide catalysts in a 3D-BER could enhance the degradation of nitrobenzene (NB) wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that modifying polyurethane sponge fillers with Fe₃O₄ and Mn₃O₄ significantly improved organic compound degradation and nitrogen/phosphorus removal, achieving high removal rates for CODCr (93.04%) and ammonia nitrogen (86.25%). Metagenomic sequencing revealed enriched microbial communities and functional genes linked to NB degradation.
population_specificity: Nitrobenzene wastewater treatment system (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Optimal voltage of 6 V and hydraulic retention time (HRT) of 24 h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mn2+-PPa nanocomplexes for targeted photodynamic therapy (PDT) and immunotherapy in osteosarcoma treatment.
results_summary: The Mn2+-PPa nanocomplexes enabled tumor-specific release and fluorescence recovery, enhancing cancer cell killing under laser irradiation. Mn2+ ions also activated the cGAS-STING pathway, boosting CD8+-mediated antitumor immune responses.
population_specificity: Osteosarcoma (primary cancer cells and immune responses in a preclinical setting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different types of manganese oxide (MnOx) in adsorbing vanadium (V) ions from acidic water for treatment applications.
results_summary: The study found that MnOx effectively adsorbed vanadium ions, with natural MnOx (NatMnO) showing the highest adsorption capacity (54.0 mg/g) at pH 3.0. Adsorption followed the Freundlich isotherm and a two-constant rate model, indicating multilayer adsorption and a mix of physical and chemical sorption. Regenerated MnOx maintained or improved its adsorption ability.
population_specificity: Acidic water treatment systems (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Mass/volume ratio of 2 g/L, concentration of 100 mg/L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manganese-containing nanoparticles (PF/MMSN@MPM) could enhance immune infiltration and improve the therapeutic efficacy of immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that PF/MMSN@MPM effectively activated the cGAS-STING pathway, enhanced immune cell infiltration, and demonstrated potent antitumor effects, especially when combined with anti-PD-1 therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical, possibly animal models given the experimental design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of manganese (Mn) and thermal acclimation on cellular energy metabolism pathways in Arctic charr, a cold-water stenotherm.
results_summary: Mn exposure combined with high temperature (16 °C) led to decreased aerobic capacity, increased glycolytic capacity, and altered enzyme activities in liver and muscle, suggesting impaired mitochondrial function. Mn bioaccumulation in gills and kidneys was higher at 7 °C, but liver and muscle accumulation was unaffected by temperature.
population_specificity: Juvenile Arctic charr (a cold-water stenothermic fish species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an enantioselective manganese(I)-catalyzed method for synthesizing chiral γ-alkoxypropyl alcohols and demonstrate its utility in drug synthesis.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a manganese(I)-catalyzed reaction producing chiral γ-alkoxypropyl alcohols with high yields and enantioselectivity, and demonstrated its application in synthesizing (S)-dapoxetine. Mechanistic studies supported a hydrogen-borrowing pathway.
population_specificity: Not applicable (chemical synthesis study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of a luteolin-manganese (Lu-Mn) nanozyme by assessing its ability to induce apoptosis and ferroptosis in tumor cells.
results_summary: The Lu-Mn nanozyme demonstrated strong affinity for H2O2, catalyzed hydroxyl radical generation in the tumor microenvironment, induced apoptosis via caspase activation, and triggered ferroptosis by inhibiting the NRF2-GPX4 pathway, showing significant antitumor efficacy in animal studies.
population_specificity: In vitro experiments and animal models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a novel Cu2O-MnO@PEG (CMP) nanomaterial in treating tumors by inducing cuproptosis and enhancing anti-tumor immune responses.
results_summary: CMP effectively mediated cuproptosis in tumor cells and enhanced anti-tumor immune responses, including improved antigen presentation, CD8+ T cell activation, and systemic immune memory. It also synergized with PD-L1 mAb to sustain anti-tumor efficacy.
population_specificity: Tumor cells and immune cells in the tumor microenvironment (in vitro or preclinical model, not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of inorganic trace minerals versus mineral methionine hydroxyl analogue chelates (MMHACs) containing manganese on broiler growth performance, carcass quality, and bone health.
results_summary: Birds fed MMHACs (M30) showed higher thigh and drumstick weights and increased ileal copper digestibility compared to those fed inorganic trace minerals, with no significant differences in gizzard erosion scores or bone parameters.
population_specificity: One-day-old Ross 308 male broiler chickens (n = 384).
effective_dosage: Mn 40 ppm (MMHAC groups M10 and M30), Mn 120 ppm (inorganic trace mineral group ITM).
study_duration: 42 days (divided into starter, grower, and finisher phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic and therapeutic potential of manganese-containing nanoparticles (AHA@MnP/QCT NPs) for non-small cell lung cancer.
results_summary: The study found that manganese (Mn²⁺) in the nanoparticles exhibited peroxidase-like activity, promoted ferroptosis, activated the cGAS-STING pathway, and enhanced MRI imaging, demonstrating effective tumor diagnosis and treatment in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of organic fertilizer and manganese-oxidizing bacteria in remediating arsenic, cadmium, and lead co-contamination in soil and their impact on maize uptake and soil health.
results_summary: Organic fertilizer promoted the transformation of heavy metals into stable forms, reducing cadmium and lead accumulation in maize roots, while manganese-oxidizing bacteria decreased arsenic bioavailability but increased cadmium and lead bioavailability. The combined treatment (BOF) achieved high fixation efficiency for all three metals and enhanced soil microbial diversity.
population_specificity: Soil and maize plants in a field experiment.
effective_dosage: 1.0% organic fertilizer; manganese-oxidizing bacteria treatment (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a rapid and efficient method for producing well-dispersed and stable MnO2 nanoparticles for biomedical applications, particularly in GSH sensing and theranostic agent delivery.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a method using tannic acid to produce stable MnO2 nanoparticles with enhanced dispersibility in biological environments. These nanoparticles demonstrated efficacy in a colorimetric assay for GSH detection and potential for loading various molecules, suggesting broad biomedical applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a two-stage bioreactor system combining Mn-oxidizing microalgae and woodchip substrates for removing Mn and nitrogen from electrolytic manganese industrial tailwater.
results_summary: The system achieved 100% Mn2+ removal, 65.69% Mn recovery, and 97% NH4+-N removal in the algae reactor, while the woodchip reactor removed 82-90% NO3--N and 65-87% total nitrogen through denitrification.
population_specificity: Electrolytic manganese industrial tailwater (not human or animal subjects).
